body: @drcrallen this fails UT
If it's preferred way to make an another PR rather than addressing exsiting PR, what's the point of making it for others? I cannot understand that.

@navis, sorry, I thought your core need with this PR was wanting a binary operator filter. In my mind that was separate from #2727, where the core need was wanting to optimize the bound filter. So that's why I did a separate PR.

If you still need a binary operator filter then I think it makes sense to keep going with this PR.

@drcrallen Ok I'll try to eliminate static configuration of namespace lookup.
As I know, druid-namespace-lookup and druid-kaka-extraction-namespace are the only two extension modules related with lookup, right?
@Hailei, what would happen if both lhsMetric and rhsMetric == null?
@binlijin I think  that both lhsMetric and rhsMetric == null  is impossible. In most case,only one of them is null.
@fjy Hours of effort to understand rebase and squash and finally make it. Does it now meet the requirement?
@gianm I'm on holiday at the moment so I haven't had time to test it yet.
Thanks @gianm so much for this wonderful commit :+1:
Looks good other than some minor comments and a desire for tests.
reopened with dynamic lookup config stuff removed.
Snuck in this change too: #2747

@binlijin @Hailei I have been able to reproduce the case where lhsMetric and rhsMetric == null in unit tests. I am not sure whether or not it would happen in practice, but it's definitely possible.  

In this case, the value of metrics[i] is set to null. The unit tests still passes, but I could imagine potential funkiness at query time.
:+1: for me
SGTM

Approach looks good.

If you are wanting JUST counts, this can be sped up by implementing this functionality at a query level, and simply returning the cardinality of the resulting filter.
With this change should single partition hash spec be deprecated?
@sirpkt The only druid.io modules, yes.
@drcrallen Addressed all the comments and reconciled with #2712 .
Cool, minor comment but :+1: after squash and travis passes.
@b-slim / @navis added docs.

Looking for thoughts on what makes sense.

IMO: filters are supposed to be filtering on values, not the entire set, so from that standpoint, it makes sense for a `null` selector to _not_ match an empty set.

But, this behavior sorta conflicts with what happens in single-value columns, where missing fields and fields equal to `[]` are "lifted" to the single value `null`. It's a bit weird for the same underlying JSON object to sometimes end up in a Druid row that matches `null` for a particular dimension, and sometimes doesn't, just based on whether that dimension is going to end up single- or multi-value.

So I guess I'm conflicted on what should happen here.

One possibility is to make it so empty sets in multi-value columns on disk don't match null (don't include those rows in that bitmap), and then make IncrementalIndex behave that way too with some logic like this:
- if we ever saw multi-values for a dimension, don't allow empty sets to match null (mimic multi-value on-disk column behavior)
- if we never saw multi-values for a dimension, do allow empty sets to match null (mimic single-value on-disk column behavior)

I believe this behavior makes sense if you think "null" is an actual value rather than meaning "not present".
#665 and #995 may provide some clues

Another possibility is to make it so empty sets always match `null`, as sort of a special case (it's special since they don't actually contain a `null` value). We could document that as something like "a filter on `null` will match any rows containing a `null` value, or any rows containing no values at all".

I believe this behavior makes sense if you think "null" means "not present".
@cheddar you may have some opinion on this given your work on #995
@drcrallen I don't follow -- are you suggesting a particular approach?

@gianm I propose a selector on null should match any of the following:
1. A dimension is missing
2. A dimension is explicitly null
3. A multi-value is zero-length `[]`
4. A multi-value explicitly contains null `["foo","bar",""]`

Since we treat columns that aren't present as if they match null (and we treat missing fields and empty arrays in JSON the same as null fields in JSON), it seems to me like Druid already has a lot of built-in bias towards treating null as "not present" rather than as an actual value.

So I'm leaning towards thinking that filters on `null` should match `[]` in multi-value columns just like they match `null` in single-value columns and like they match all rows if there is no column.
@drcrallen I think I agree with you
@drcrallen `""` should not be part of the spec, `""` is an optimization detail at the column storage level. The only thing we should tell the user about `""` is that they get mapped to `null`
I agree with @xvrl regarding not focusing on `""` and just call it `null`

In your hypothetical string example, lets say we have `"AZ"` and `"BZ"`  as dimension values, and we have a filter which matches strings that start with A and end with Z using the method proposed. For a simple filter case you would expect "AZ" to be returned, and thus for the negation case you would expect "BZ" to be returned.

But if I ask for a NOT of the filter, the getBimapIndex would allow the cursor to advance to `"BZ"` and the makeMatcher would exclude it, so you would end up with no results.

In a crazier case, if you just had `"A"` and `"Z"` as dimension values, the filter of "starts with A and ends with Z" evaluated using the method previously proposed, would match neither value. But if you did a NOT of the filter, you would exclude the "starts with A" bitmap, leaving you Z when generating the cursor, then exclude the "Z" field when iterating through the values.

This issue arrises from an implicit boolean connection between the two steps in the special filter that is not preserved in the `not` filter.

If I have miss-read part of the methodology please let me know.
@du00cs Thanks for the effort :). Rebasing and squashing helps us maintain a clean commit history and makes it easy to backport fixes.
@jon-wei some more merge conflicts
@jon-wei marking this as WIP for now
:+1:, please squash commits.
@drcrallen @b-slim
@r4ruchir anything?
I feel like having the selector match both `["foo","bar",""]` and `[]` is really strange. Would anyone ever want that on purpose?
@vogievetsky IMHO if they don't want to match on null they shouldn't put null in the multi-value set. The only reason it would be put there is because they want to use it in filtering.
:+1: after travis
@nishantmonu51 what is the % improvement?
@navis any chance of finishing this up?

Rebased, there are changes to BoundFilter from merging with https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2727
- If extractionFn is defined, the optimization for finding start/end index is not used
- extractionFn is applied in doesMatch() function
@vogievetsky does that also mean `[]` should be able to be treated differently than `[""]`?
@vogievetsky byRow filters will probably be added at some point (#2217 proposes them, for example) so let's assume we are only talking about non-byRow filters right now.
Closing this pending implementation of https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2742
BTW also going with @drcrallen suggestion and just telling people not to put nulls in MV dimension sets unless they know what they are doing is fine I think.
@sirpkt can you expand more on the pain points here? There are some pretty cutting changes in the proposed PR and I'm not quite getting the main pain they are solving.
Strongly suggest fixing https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2602#discussion_r57613146 but the rest is at the author's discretion. :+1:

@drcrallen Thanks for the feedback, let me update this proposal in a bit, it doesn't currently handle boolean filters properly as you mentioned, (e.g., even without the hypothetical filter, a selector on string OR with selector on float wouldn't work properly either).
PR #2753 makes things behave such that filtering on null DOES match empties.
I think it good to handle all case.
Would appreciate it if anyone who cares about null handling could take a look.
@drcrallen yes I assumed that `[]` and `[""]` would be treated differently. I am guessing that is not straightforward given how Druid stores data?
@binlijin in convertV8toV9, `nullsSet` is only used for conversion of multi-value columns to single-value columns; so it's not used if a column is going to remain multi-value.

`[]` and `[""]` could be treated differently in multi-value columns, as they are stored differently (first is `[]` and second is `[""]`). In single-value columns they are stored the same way (as a single `""` value).
Thank you very much @gianm.

@drcrallen 

Here are my current thoughts on the boolean filtering:

I suppose the general issue is that "filter cursor offsets using bitmap, then apply value matcher" only works if the conditions on either side are parts of an AND (implicit in the pruning), doing OR wouldn't work. 

One option could be to convert filters to conjunctive normal form, which is what @navis does in: https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/2217. 

A combination of filters would be converted into a set of AND clauses. This set of AND clauses would then be partitioned into two sets:
- First set contains AND clauses containing filters that can use bitmap indexes
- Second set contains AND clauses with at least one filter requiring a column scan

The first set would be used to create bitmap index during cursor generation, the second set is applied as a ValueMatcher during iteration.

I suppose it would also be possible to allow this two-stage filtering to work with an OR split, i.e.:
- Bitmaps are used not as a pre-filter but as a "cache" of matched rows (don't pre-filter any rows, check the bitmap first before appying ValueMatcher to rows during column scan)
- Maybe accompanied with a similar filter transformation to disjunctive normal form? (set of OR clauses)

Maybe a viable approach would be to let the user configure this aspect of filtering behavior:
- Query-level option that configures whether to convert filters to CNF, DNF, or leave user-provided filters as-is
  - This could address situations where the normalized form is needlessly complex/inefficient, let the user manually arrange the AND/OR clauses if needed
- If top-level filter is AND, use bitmaps as filter
- If top-level filter is OR, use bitmaps as matched row "cache"
- If top-level is NOT, convert boolean children accordingly and then apply the rules above

Returning to the example you provided with a NOT on an AND filter on two of my hypothetical string filters, maybe it's better to postpone support for allowing a single non-boolean filter to return both a bitmap index and value matcher. There would have to be a new way for the individual filter to express whether the returned bitmap index/valuematcher pair is in an AND relation or an OR relation, and none of the current filters seem like they would require support for that feature.

@navis can you squash commits?
@pjain1 there's some more merge conflicts

It sounds good to me to skip allowing the basic filters to return both bitmaps and value matchers. You're right that we don't really have a use case for that right now.

however- I think it'd still be good for a particular filter class to be able to decide to do a bitmap index vs a value matcher depending on the actual column capabilities, rather than as a class-level thing. For example a selector filter would want to return a bitmap on a string dimension but a value matcher on a column that doesn't have an index (like `__time` or a numeric dimension without an index).
@navis any chance of addressing these comments?
agreed, I think returning bitmap/value matcher should be dynamically chosen based on the column capabilities
@navis can we update docs/content/development/extensions.md? Also create a new page for the docs for this extension
@drcrallen scopes in pom are all updated

Finally got it signed and attached here.

Thanks,
Ruchir
